questions.question: Sam ................................... his homework for two years.
questions.description: The present perfect continuous tense is used to talk about actions or situations that started in the past and has continued up to the present.

questions.question: We ................................ a strange experience yesterday.
questions.description: The simple past is used to say when something happened in the past.

questions.question: He .................................... for Singapore last week.
questions.description: The simple past is used to say when something happened in the past.

questions.question: See that you ................................... disturb the patients.
questions.description: The simple present is used in imperative structures.

questions.question: You will win if you .................................. hard.
questions.description: In the first conditional we use the simple present tense in the if-clause and will + first form of the verb in the main clause.structures.

questions.question: The post mortem report proved that the man ........................................ ten hours ago.
The train .................................. by the time we reached the station.
questions.description: We use the past perfect for the earlier of two past actions.

questions.question: Every morning, I .................................. for 30 minutes.
questions.description: The simple present is used to talk about habitual actions in the present.

questions.question: He .................................... school at fifteen.
questions.description: The simple past is used to talk about finished past events.

questions.question: You cannot meet him now. He ................................ home.
questions.description: The present perfect is used to talk about finished events whose effect is still felt in the present.

questions.question: When we visited her she ................................. bed ridden for six months.
If you ……………………………… to me, you wouldn’t land in trouble.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.
